Mindful Practices: SEL for Administrators
Identifying the Areas of Need for SEL Growth

Sources of Stress

Since 2015, Mindful Practices has collaborated with Dr. Kiljoong Kim at Chapin Hall at the University of Chicago to refine our efficacy and approach. This has led to measurable impact. Through this partnership, Dr. Kim and his team conducted a study during the 2018-2019 school year exploring the ways in which students and teachers may directly or indirectly affect one another through the lens of stress and well-being.

As you read the article, think about your school community and what may be some of the sources of stress experienced by your school/district staff?

Read the Sources of Stress Research Brief by Chapin Hall, 2021

Take the Educator Pre-/Post- Self-Assessment below (and/or share this self-assessment) with your staff to help identify your areas of need for SEL growth and well-being for yourself, staff, and students.

How strongly do you agree or disagree with the following statements?

1. I understand how levels of energy (both my students’ and mine) impact my classroom dynamic. I understand the energy and emotions that I am bringing into the classroom.

Strongly
Disagree Strongly
Agree

2. I take the time to understand and address my own well-being needs. I have the resources I need for proactive mindfulness, breathing, and/or movement or yoga activities consistently.

Strongly
Disagree Strongly
Agree

3. I honor the well-being needs of my students. We practice (and I model) mindfulness, breathing, and/or movement or yoga activities that help us focus, concentrate, and be present in the classroom setting.

Strongly
Disagree Strongly
Agree

4. I regularly embed anti-racist teachings into my lessons. I consistently work on examining my own biases and provide instructions through a culturally responsive lens.

Strongly
Disagree Strongly
Agree

5. I articulate clear, explicit expectations for my students with their SEL work. I understand that students (and adults) have different entry points to SEL and I provide my instruction through a compassionate and trauma-informed lens.

Strongly
Disagree Strongly
Agree

6. I believe it is part of my shared responsibility to make sure that each student has a caring adult to connect with daily, whether it is me or another educator or staff member in the school building.

Strongly
Disagree Strongly
Agree

7. I create a classroom climate that honors student voice and agency and promotes positive identity.

Strongly
Disagree Strongly
Agree

8. I model healthy lifestyle choices around food and drink (sugar, caffeine, nutritionally void foods, etc.) for my students.

Strongly
Disagree Strongly
Agree

9. I reflect on my practices as an educator and work hard to develop my own Social-Emotional Competency (SEC). I model the behaviors I want my students to exhibit. I own that I am a role model.

Strongly
Disagree Strongly
Agree

10. I can communicate with my peers with voice and agency. I can set boundaries with my colleagues, administrators, and my students’ parents regarding my time and can effectively manage their expectations.

Strongly
Disagree Strongly
Agree

Thank you for submitting your feedback!


Reflect

After reading the Sources of Stress article and taking the self-assessment, how do you think your own SEC (social-emotional competence) influences your ability to effectively lead your department/school building/district? How does teacher SEC influence their ability to effectively lead their classrooms?
